subject: Re: [junit] Why must test methods return void?
msgSnippet: Duncan, ... I can imagine a value in _allowing_ certain classes to override the validation behavior, but not as much value in loosening the class validation by
messageBody:
Duncan,

On Fri, Jan 22, 2010 at 1:17 PM, dmcg123 <duncan@...> wrote:
> After over 10 years of using JUnit, it has only just struck me that test methods must return void, but why?

I can imagine a value in _allowing_ certain classes to override the
validation behavior, but not as much value in loosening the class
validation by default.

For me, imagine someone writes this as their first JUnit test:

@Test public boolean threeIsPrime() {
PrimeAnalyzer a = new PrimeAnalyzer();
return a.isPrime(3);
}

This test is likely to not do what its author intended. Pushing this
author to understand how JUnit works a little better provides value,
and I haven't yet seen a proposal for loosening return value
restrictions that provides more value.

As an example:

> I've just come across an example where a particular test did a lot of work, and I wanted to piggy-back on its final state by calling the method from another test.

It seems to me that this pattern would solve this desire, at the cost
of just one additional extracted method:

private BigThing doALotOfWorkToMakeABigThing() { ... }

@Test public void basicBigThing() {
assertEquals(Size.BIG, doALotOfWorkToMakeABigThing().size());
}

@Test public void shrink() {
BigThing thing = doALotOfWorkToMakeABigThing();
thing.shrink();
assertEquals(Size.SMALL, thing.size());
}

> Is there any fundamental reason for not allowing me to return values? It might even be an opportunity to write an annotation expressing constraints about the value returned.

What would be the advantage of writing assertions as annotations
rather than plain old Java?

Thanks,

David Saff
